prose.s:
The month ended.
meñye āra
Tenth month. meññe śkante
From day of the month ten onward to śimprāyai śopai , in sum: śak meñyatsemeṃ mante śimprāyai śopaiś ṣe keś

We ground wheat: ysā
re waltsām
thirty nine piculs, eight pecks. täryāka ñu cakaṃnma ok tom
Śāṅke ground it. śāṅke wāltsa

The Sthere Dharmarakṣite knew about it.
sthere dharmarakṣite śarsa
The Sthere Ślawarme knew about it. sthere ślawarme śarsa

On the parramañi of the warwaltsai , we bought bovine oil:
warwaltsaitse parramañine kewye ṣalywe käryāmte
three pints, trai ṣaṅkäṃ
we gave three pecks wheat for each: piśśār tom ysāre wsam
a picul, five pecks. cāk piś tom

We bought paṣkaro-oil:
paṣkaroṣe ṣalywe käryāmte
four pints, śwer ṣaṅkäṃ
for wheat: eight pecks. ysāresa ok tom

We bought three pints of sauce for six pecks wheat.
tsyāṅk trai ṣaṅkäṃ käryāmte ṣkas tom ysāresa

We gave the aslyaimaṣai-wheat to the Sthere Dharmarakṣite:
sthere dharmarakṣitetse aslyaimaṣai ysāre päst wsam
five piculs, two pecks. piś cakaṃnma wi tom

The month ended.
meññe āra
Eleventh month. meñye warsaññe

On day of the month six, for the clothing of the kapyāri, the Toṅkā Ṣarmire conveyed wheat to sell in the city: ṣkas meñyatsene kapyāres wäsitseś
ysāre rine plyasi wāya toṅkā ṣarmire
ten piculs. śak cakaṃnma
The novice's finger-measure. ṣarmiretse kapci

For the reception of Prajñākarasome, we bought bovine oil:
prajñākarasometse wrätsaiseś kewye ṣalywe käryāmte
three pints, trai ṣaṅkäṃ
with wheat: a picul, five pecks. ysāresa cāk piś tom

On the order of the adjutant kurriṅkāte, the mid summer levies had been apportioned (?) back.
simā kurriṅkāteṃtse yaitkorsa ywārś ṣmañe pauśyenta aṣkār sasākauwa ṣeyeṃ

We gave the wheat to Cāsām, a soldier going to yāwyeṃ: yāywyeṃ ykuweś re
cye cāsāmtse ysāre wsam
thirteen piculs, five pecks. śak tärya cakaṃnma piś tom
There is a receipt. ṣau nesäṃ

We bought mlyokotau-oil for the day of the full moon in the eleventh month:
wärsaññe pälentiś mlyokotauṣṣe ṣalywe käryāmte
four pints, eight pecks, for wheat. śwer ṣaṅkäṃ ok tom ysāresa

Pakeñe worked for four days for patalakṣāṣṣes (?).
patalakṣāṣṣeṃs pakeñe śwer komtsa laṃṣṣāte
As a wage, he took wheat: pito ysāre kamāte
a picul, two pecks. cāk wi tom

We bought ynaikenta-shoes for Mikkaswiñi,
mikkaswiñitse ynaikenta hkhainta käryām
for wheat: five pecks. ysāresa piś tom

comments.comment: śimprāyai almost certainly has something to do with śimpraye in THT 1574 a6
For a tentative explanation of these two terms, see and .
For the name, cf THT 289 a2 tᵤṅā. connect it to Niya Prakrit toṃga, Runic Turkic Toŋa and Uyghur Toŋa. In Gāndhārī, toṃga- is used as a title.
For wrätsaise, cf. THT 2712 a7, Kucha 0190 a2.
For hkhai as a loan from Chinese 鞋, see and .

transcription.prose:
tnek ptace pakreṣṣai lāṃs aspawār tarya tmane wiltse pi
ś käṃnte pśāka : wi wässanmaś cāñi piś tmane ṣkas yiltse
wi käṃnte ikäṃ ok : krośśemaṃñe käryau wi käṃnte śak kaummasa
alekak yāśa kaumñes pauśye eñcil kaṃnte ikäṃ kaummasa

translation.line: Therein, the the procession work aspawār: thirty two thousand five
hundred fifty two (coins). Coins for clothes: fifty six thousand
two hundred twenty eight. A krośśe-maṃñe (was) bought for two hundred ten bolts of silk.
Another thing: yāsa was levied for the kaumñes: one hundred twenty bolts of silk.

line.tr: Mitrasome, Śāntisene, (and) Puttawarme the Moko. (The people) of Ynaimyā carried (here) the coins (produced in? / as the price of?) the field: one thousand
five hundred. (The four limits) of this field belong to the monastery: on the east the river Armoki (is) the boundary;
on the south the branch of the river Yāte (is) the boundary; on the west the great canal (is) the boundary;
on the north the branch of the river Armoki (is) the boundary, just until the great canal.
The mark of a lion on the clay (?) (is) seen on the verso.
